results.title: Shock to the system
results.creator_credit: Jan Egleson, Patrick McCormick and Corsair Pictures
results.brief_description: Graham Marshall (Michael Caine) is a middle-aged New York advertising exec recently passed over in a sure fire promotion to a younger subordinate (Peter Riegert). Suffering the effects of this crushing oversight, Graham inadvertently pushes a panhandler into the oncoming path of a subway train, killing the man instantly. Charged with murder, Graham is released on manslaughter. This leads him to speculate on the possibility of repeating his actions - murder, camouflaged as accident - and plots to get back at some of his enemies, starting at home with his shrewish wife (Swoosie Kurtz). The downtrodden suit has turned into a likeable avenger. This parable of corporate greed in post 1980s Wall Street is a curious mix of thriller and black comedy. Cast also includes Will Patton as the obligatory gumshoe and Elizabeth McGovern as the sympathetic co-worker and love interest. Based on the novel by Simon Brett.

results.title: Sherman's march: a meditation on the possibility of romantic love in the South during an era of nuclear weapons proliferation
results.brief_description: A journey by the filmmaker through the South follows the route of the Union’s General Sherman who carried on the war against the civilian population of the Confederacy, then largely female. Along the way McElwee is confronted by the mysteries of Southern womanhood in his encounters with eight women. His dreams are haunted by the spectre of nuclear war and he encounters signs of its pervasiveness along the way. McElwee assesses the state of his movie as he goes along, on the soundtrack and in a series of soliloquies to the camera.

results.title: Shellfish gathering
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Alcheringa”.
Migratory habits of inland Aborigines who go walkabout to the coast to collect shellfish at certain times of the year, to augment their diet. The husband walks ahead and carries his fire sticks in his hair. His wife goes into the rock pools and quickly fills the string bag which hangs from her shoulder; cooks the fish in their shells in the hot ash; water is poured over the fire to cool the shellfish before they are removed and eaten.

results.title: Mutton birds
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Alcheringa (A)”.
Aborigines gather eggs and hunt the mutton bird on small coastal islands. The birds are removed from their burrows, killed and plucked before being loaded onto bark floats to be carried through the surf back to the camp fire.

results.title: Making a stone axe
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Alcheringa”.
Shows how Australia’s First Nations peoples lived hundreds of years ago. Tool making require both skill and patience. By means of grinding stones, the stone axe is shaped to the desired form.

results.title: Shock corridor
results.creator_credit: Samuel Fuller and Allied Artists Pictures
results.brief_description: Peter Breck plays an ambitious reporter, Johnny Barrett, who decides to imitate an insane psychiatric patient in order to write an expose on conditions in a psychiatric asylum where a murder has recently been committed. He finds himself losing the grip on his own sanity when he confronts his fellow inmates who all exhibit paranoiac and delusional fantasies. Before long Johnny is no more sane than any of the other men inside. Samuel Fuller’s intense thriller is a searing and truly frightening dissection of American social malaise. Johnny’s fellow inmates all exhibit schizophrenic and psychotic behaviour that is reflective of the social divisions in their contemporary culture. A black man, so psychically disfigured by racism, believes himself to be a white man in the Ku Klux Klan; a man thinks he is a Civil War General because he can not deal with the stigma of being branded a “Commie”. Within the limitations of a B-movie budget, Fuller has created one of the finest and most caustic metaphors for the damage inflicted on the national psyche by the Cold War and the orgy of witch-hunts initiated by the McCarthy-era blacklist.

results.title: Shoalwater: up for grabs
results.creator_credit: Helen Stickley-Thompson, David Bradbury and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: This film is about a group of people fighting for the preservation of Shoalwater Bay (Queensland). With its sweeping bays, untouched golden beaches, its jungle and rainforest, 200 metre high sand-dunes (purported to be the oldest in the world), Shoalwater Bay is home to a multitude of birds, plants and wildlife. But this is all under threat due to both the Federal and Queensland State Governments issuing exploratory sandmining leases to several Australian and Japanese mining companies - the justification being the potential creation of jobs. However, there are many who would dispute the actual number of jobs which will become available and who argue that this unique part of Queensland’s coastline must be preserved at all costs. Produced by Award-Winning Documentary filmmaker, David Bradbury and narrated by Peter Garrett (of Midnight Oil fame).

results.title: Hunting a kangaroo
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Alcheringa (A)”.
Shows Aborigines out hunting for an important source of food, the kangaroo; using boomerang and woomera which are made especially for the purpose. Introduced by Bill Onus and narrated by John Morgan.

results.title: Fishing
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Alcheringa”.
Illustrates the fishing methods of some Australian First Nations people, shown fishing on a lake using three-pronged spears from bark canoes. With Bill Onus.

results.title: Shepherd's pie and sushi
results.creator_credit: Mieko Ouchi, Craig Anderl, Jerry Krepakevich, National Film Board of Canada and 100 Miles Film Group
results.brief_description: Mieko Ouchi is an aspiring actress, half Celtic and half Japanese, who is cast in The War Between Us, a film on the World War II internment of 22,000 Japanese-Canadians, in the midst of researching her own documentary about this key episode in her own family’s history. The program investigates questions of personal and cultural identity as Mieko discovers more and more about her past and her heritage as the filming progresses and the complex implications of hers and her family’s struggle to come to terms with their sense of displacement in both Canadian and Japanese society. An autobiographical documentary as well as family chronicle, this documentary also elucidates a strained period in Japanese-Canadian history through the use of archival footage, interviews with the Ouchi family, dramatic re-enactments and excerpts from The War Between Us.
